But they aren't good for you at all.   Overall:  This place isn't full of people who are trying to be seen.  It's the perfect "roll out of bed and throw on a hoodie" breakfast spot that doesn't break the bank but definitely fills your stomach.  The service is always great.   S&Gs, please don't ever change :)

I recently got up one particularly groggy Saturday morning to make steak and eggs using my stove and charcoal grill. I charred the steak beyond recognition by leaving it on the grill too long. The steak was then thrown out in pieces after trying to cut it up into some sort of useful, somewhat tasty meat, as this hapless effort failed miserably. Thankfully, S&G was right down the street, and what a delicious breakfast/brunch gem of an establishment this place is. Extremely fast service, great servers (the place is owned by three families and it always appears that everyone is related to one another), great coffee, countless menu options, and everything served fresh with every possible spread you could imagine for toast, your entree, etc. To top it all off, every single table in the place contains two bottles of random hot sauce. (Being a huge hot sauce fan, this is a major plus). You know how when you walk out of a mediocre breakfast place and upon exiting you turn to your friend/significant other/spouse/partner and say something to the effect of, "you know, that kinda sucked, we shouldn't go back there - I can't put my finger on what was wrong, but it was just, blah." Well, upon exiting S&G, you will feel a) full of delicious food, and b) counting down the 24 hours left before it's breakfast/brunch time again. Do not miss the Athenian Egg Casserole. Feta+gyro meat+eggs+hash browns+onions+peppers = pure breakfast bliss. Turning back to the steak debacle, upon returning from S&G that fateful Saturday morning, we discovered that the dog got into the trash, devoured what was left of the charred meat and ended up with explosive diarrhea for two days. It's a good thing we had S&G there to keep us good and stuffed with non-explosive deliciousness. Damn dog.

I really appreciated the friendliness of the employees, but the food was just okay. The green beans were completely flavorless; I know big batches of green beans at a diner aren't gonna be amazing, but it was like eating chewy green paper. My chicken sandwich and fries were very salty. Maybe if they'd used a little of the fry salt in the beans... The location's convenient, the staff is cool, but I don't think I'll be going back. I took half my sandwich and the fries home for later. The waitress said "no beans?" Nope, no beans.
The staff is nice, the place is clean but the food is just not anything outstanding. Nothing I couldnt cook myself :/ and its all pretty heavy. Sorry S&G.

My favorite diner? And maybe my bestie's too given it's called "sam and george's" -- but jokes apart, this place was awesome! In an area with plenty of parking, spacious un-cramped diner, chirpy servers, warm welcome, fresh food, awesome menu selection, huge portions, right price, what's there to improve here!?  We really enjoyed our egg casseroles and they even had greek toast!

Sam & George's is one of my favorite spots for breakfast/lunch/brunch in the city. Now I'm a man of simple tastes, and Sam & George's satisfies all of them.  From the awesome owner who welcomes everyone in the door like you were coming into his home...to the selection of casseroles/skillets...to the bottomless cup of coffee..to the expansive menu that I haven't put a dent in after 2 years...to grandma ringing you up as you leave, everything is just the way I like it. I knew I had found my place when the very first time my GF and I went.   I enjoyed my bowl of homemade soup so much (did I mention the delicious soups?) the owner came over and gave me another bowl on the house.  That was before I got my perfectly executed patty melt and she got her turkey melt packed with real off-the-bone turkey that tasted like Thanksgiving. My GF looked at me and said "I don't think I've ever seen you so happy".  We've been return customers ever since and have seldom been disappointed.

I am rating S&G a five star not because of the food but the memory. Since before I was born my grandmother would start her morning at the golden apple then move over by johnny once they opened. I would visit her on weekends and then wake up at 8am and walk next door and eat. My family would come and all get together and eat.  Okay now to the food, yes its a diner but the food is great, and the size is better. Everything is really fresh and cooked to order. I would remember my younger years walking home from the bar 3am and would see Johnny's father inside squeezing oranges for the Orange juice.  Eat here and keep local places alive!!
Come here hungry and don't expect to eat an entire skillet if you don't have the correct mindset and complete willpower over your body.

Three of us woke up on Sunday morning with a serious need for "diner breakfast".  After a quick Yelp search, we were on our way to Sam & George's.  There was a line, but it moved quickly and the owner was constantly there to take care of anyone who was waiting. Did we want coffee, water or pop? If so, it was brought in less than 30 seconds.  They turn tables pretty fast here and the bus boys are seriously some of the quickest and most talented I've seen. After 10 minutes or so, we were seated in a booth in the front of the restaurant.  The menu is a little overwhelming. Just because you have 200 ways to combine your ingredients, doesn't mean you should list them all.  My two companions each got one of the famed skillet melt things while I ordered a bowl of soup. I know. Weird. BUT while waiting in line, I had seen at least 6 people order the soup with a little basket of rolls and thought they must know something I didn't.  Our server was young and probably inexperienced. She didn't remember who ordered what or that I'd asked for the rolls with my soup (the rolls cost extra). My soup actually didn't come out until about 5 minutes after everyone else's food cause it was forgotten.  The "homemade" chicken with rice soup tasted... okay. I didn't have a single piece of chicken in the whole bowl, and it didn't taste too terribly different than Progresso, so I'm not sure what the big deal was. After my rolls were forgotten, I asked for a side of hash browns instead. These were also forgotten in the window for some time, but when they finally did come out, they were good. You can tell a LOT of butter went into the making of those potatoes.  Both the skillets were pretty gross. Both guys I was with are pretty big eaters and they both left more than half their meals on the table. The quality of ingredients just wasn't there, and at a pretty high price for diner breakfast food, I expected more than undercooked bacon and what tasted like canned mushrooms thrown on top of hashbrowns and covered with globs of cheddar cheese and scrambled eggs. Yuck.  Sorry Sam & Georges. The owner seems like an awesome guy and the bus boys work their tails off, but the service and the food were enough to turn me off for good.

I don't know if I can say anything more than all the other reviews haven't.  Friendly people, good for kids, acceptable portions for the price...in short, its one of the better (and better kept) establishments in the area.  My only complaint is that it can get so crowded during the weekend mornings!  =P

I have yet to be disappointed with this place.  I strive to one day be a hash brown connoisseur...with that in mind I always order hash browns when I go out for breakfast and this place...Sam and George's, is my golden standard for what good hash browns are. I have not found a place to top these guys...and I don't know if I ever will.

My boyfriend grew up in the neighborhood and talked about this place, but we didn't visit together until last weekend.  I'm sure we will be back.  When I'm in the mood for a good breakfast I don't want to have to wait in a long line for a table and then forever to get my food.  This place was quick, clean and tasty...not too fancy.  You can show up after church or just throw on a pair of jeans.  No need to get all decked out for a fancy brunch.   They have great options for skillets, omelets, pancakes etc. and don't get in a tizzy if you ask to change something up a little bit.  Breakfast is such a simple meal yet so many places can't get it right.  S&G definitely can!  I would recommend this place to anyone looking for a good breakfast standby.

I used to live in lakeview back in the day and that is how i first found this place.  In fact, it was my second meal after I moved here over 6 years ago.  I live in a totally different neighborhood..probably only a few miles away but in the land of food...there are just too many options inbetween.  Well, today I woke up super hungover and the only thing that could put that to rest was s & g.  I don't think we have been in this place for two years and the owner took one look at us and says, "Heeeyyy!  How have you been?"  I love that.  But, the awesome thing about it....he is like that to all customers.   So lets talk food.  The menu is gigantic.  I have had their egg skillets before but it's been a while.  I had a sandwich with tater tots.  It also came with soup.  We ordered a half cut up watermelon too that was just soo tasty.  I'm sure it's probably pretty standard diner food options but when the food and service is good...this is how this place has around for 50 years.

I have been coming to S&G since I was a little girl for family breakfast. and when I say family I mean my grandpa and a bunch of aunts my mom everyone kids. They are always so accommodating making room for all of us quickly and bringing out every ones food together and hot. Its all just good breakfast food and they have tons of yummy skillets to pick from. It is definitely a neighbor hood place which I hope will be around for me to bring my grand kids for breakfast.

We've been going to S & G for breakfast at least a couple of times a month for several years and I have to say that it's one of the most consistently great breakfast experiences I've had in Chicago.  An old-fashioned diner with no gimmicks, no "scene"- just fantastic breakfast. The service is above par- the super-friendly, efficient waitstaff means customers feel welcome and your coffee cups stay full. The food always arrives VERY quickly and exactly as you ordered it. The menu is enormous (and accounts for nearly every sandwich or lunch/dinner dish you can image) but we've really only tried breakfast.  Personal favorite: Hobo Banquet with broccoli (hash browns, egg, cheese, broccoli).  mmmmmmm! We LOVE that they always have huge amounts of fresh fruit available, as well.

Oh Sam and George's...you left me wanting so much more especially for how much you charged!! My room mate and I came for brunch. The menu is  as advertised here and there are plenty of options to choose from. We each went with a skillet. The food was nothing noteworthy. It is standard diner food, which if you are looking for a hangover cure might be right up your alley.  The impeccable customer service bumps my review up a rating. The owner takes real pride in his restaurant.

Oh, I really enjoyed this place.  I had breakfast at the counter with a friend on a busy Sunday afternoon.  It was packed, of course, but I loved being able to sit at the counter and watch the owner and his family work together.  His mother still works the cash register and greets customers as they enter.   This is standard Greek diner food and it's amazing!

Went once, will never go back.  The Guy at the front is not friendly and has gone off on customers and his own staff.   It's not cute or funny.  His staff is terrified of him and they'll whisper that to you as they're pouring the dishwater-flavored coffee. Make sure to review your check.  They do nickle and dime you for every request (charge for an extra butter, seriously!).   God forbid you ask the Guy about the charges for the extras - you'll get bounced out so fast your head will spin. If you want a good diner experience, there are dozens of other places within a few minutes. Your choice.  If decide to go, I hope you have a pleasant experience rather the extremely unpleasant experience that I and my party had when we went.   Who needs that?!

I had to do a review to off set that "gastronome" douche! I'm here once a week if not more. I absolutely love this diner! I love the owner and wait staff and i love the service and attention to detail from all of the employee's. I go here cause it feels good to be here. They treat everyone well and want you to enjoy your meal. I am always happy with my food. And they are awesome about making sure your coffee doesn't get low. Joe H's special (skillet) or the Denver omelette with a side of corned beef hash. I'm gettin hungry thinkin about it.

I thought that this was the friendliest dinner that I have ever been to. I can totally imagine myself living next to this and becoming a regular. We ordered the tex mex skillet & the Joe's special. They were both just average.

This place is horrid. A fellow gastronome and myself headed here this morning with high hopes, based on the Yelp rating.  One of our favorite places, Bakin and Eggs, is just a few doors down, but we decided to pass in favor of a new adventure.  Boy, were we disappointed. The food was sub-par, something you might expect at a Denny's or Ram's horn.  I don't understand what all of the buzz is about.  The only thing that was exciting was the kitschy decor - local teams plaques hung on the wall and random art scattered about. So, we agreed it was ok, and would probably settle on rating this eatery a 2 or 3 on Yelp.  Until we went to the front to pay.  Yikes. Well, the itemized bill said .50 next to potatoes well done and I asked what the extra charge was for.  They told me it was probably for the sourdough bread I ordered (is there really a valid reason for an upcharge on 2 slices of sourdough over two slices of white or rye?  REALLY?)  My friend said, okay, well you should tell people that when they order.  The owner came over and snarled that it was written on the menu.  We explained that we read it pretty thoroughly and did not notice and suggested waitresses might mention that there is an upcharge whenever someone orders something that requires one - just a friendly piece of advice; feedback from a customer. Well, that didn't go over so well.  The owner started yelling us and telling us we should eat somewhere else then, including some obscenities.  He also went on a tangent saying that we had four dollar drinks from Starbucks in our hands, so we could probably handle paying the fifty cents and that fifty cents is not a lot of money.  Thank god he didn't notice her Louis Vuitton bag.  My friend responded that we might next time, but that it wasn't about the money, it was just the principle and that we couldn't understand why he was so upset about our suggestion.  He then screamed, "Please don't come here ever again".  Whoa - what an idiot.  Oh, and by the way, it cost just as much money to eat at this dump as it would have to go to Bakin and Eggs or Bongo Room or somewhere else delicious.

This place is just the diner I've been looking for not too far from my apartment. With all the chic places that have poped up that serve breakfast, sometimes I just want a no frills diner. Upon walking in the owner showed us our options for seats. Throughout the lunch he was walking around not only hosting but serving, cleaning tables, and being actively involved in all that was going on in the place. The menu at this place is massive but has a lot to offer. The soups are pretty on point and I love that they come with the assorted basket of odd rolls. For the amount of food, the price is right on. I also loved that Yia-Yia was running the cash register.

I'm here now and it's great! The food is made with fresh ingredients, the staff are polite and friendly and it's amazingly clean. It's refresing to experience this combo at a local restaurant. (from Melody C., Scott L's fiancée)

Talk about a classic diner in our classic city. This place has it all; an extensive menu with an entire page devoted to skillets, pushy yet warm waitresses, and one of those spinning dessert trays on the counter.  My brother introduced me to this place because he is addicted to the 'Wayne's skillet." I'm not completely sure what is in it, but it looked like a hybrid Denver Omelet skillet with spicy sausage added. What do I like to eat there? It is a personal policy of mine to order the same sando at every diner I go to, just because I know it will be good. No diner can mess up a grilled cheese with bacon and tomato, side of fries, chocolate milkshake. So bomb. Check this place out anytime.

One of my favorite places for breakfast in Chicago.  Back when I lived in the neighborhood not a weekend went by that I did not have a breakfast at the good old S&G.  So much better than the Golden Crapple across the street.   Sometimes I struggle between breakfast and lunch items as I love the soups here.  I am not a fan of cream soups, but the Cream of Chicken Rice on Sunday is great.  Saturday Lentil is tasty as well.
best place around.food is and always great.good for families.treat u like familyLove this place

S&G S&G S&G!!! Yayyy I've finally found it!  After having been horrrrribly misguided to places such as Stella's Diner and Wishbone, I'm happy to discover that a very good breakfast restaurant DOES exist in Lakeview!! VERY large menu-which I guess can be viewed as a good thing or a bad thing. I choose good. 26 skillets to chose from. Don't waste your time with the other stuff, you want a skillet.  I had the Dudley Dooright-Hash Browns, Sautéed Onions, Tomatoes, Diced Canadian Bacon, Swiss Cheese with Two over easy Eggs.  I added Jalepenos bc they make everything THAT much better! yummmmm The little things count: English muffin was enormous and perfectly toasted.  The coffee was fantastic.  OJ (FRESH SQEEZED) - the best!!! The staff-omg-couldn't say a bad thing about them-Truly exceptional customer service! Thanks for a great breaskast, I'll be back soon!

What a nice find!  Open until 4, which worked for us....a little late start to our Sunday Funday.   If everyone who had mediocre hashbrowns allowed a tot substitution, I would eat more tots.  I love tots.  I especially loved these tots.  Golden, perfect, tottasticness.   I had scrambled eggs (meh), wheat toast (YUM!!), bacon (YUM YUM!!!), and the aforementioned tots.  My friend's was identical except for over easy (yum) and a croissant (HOLY YUM YUM!!!)

There isn't a single bad thing to say about S&G's.  The owner guy is always up front chatting with everyone. My friend thinks he's too friendly- but my friend is also a grouch.  The reason you go to S&Gs is for the skillets. Many hangovers have been cured by their skillets. There are 20 of them- go for the popeye or the porky pig (ham, bacon and sasuage).  I love that any waitress will refill your coffee when walking by- in so many places the waitresses don't work together.  If there is a wait at S&G's, don't head across the street to the Golden Apple. I have no issues with the apple, but the reason that S&G's has a wait is because its better.

Everytime my parents come in town, we get breakfast/brunch at this restaurant.  The service is outstanding.  There is always a line on the weekends, but they are so fast at getting you seated and getting your order out, that you never have to wait too long.   If you're wondering what to get, you must try one of the skillets.  I always read them all and debate whether to try something new, but I always go back for the avocado.  Hashbrowns on the bottom, then a layer of avocado, melted cheese and eggs on top...it's hard to go wrong. You even get toast/jelly on the side!  Thinking about it makes me want to go there for breakfast this weekend!!!

Clean, great food, great service Let me preface this review by saying I've been living in Chicago since July and have yet to find a breakfast joint that I really liked.  I think this is that place.  I stopped in here after reading the reviews on yelp and I loved the place.  I had a  combination omelet (basically a western omelette w/ tomatoes and mushrooms) and a coffee.  The omelette was exactly how I like it, with the cheese melted on the inside (I find it strange that a lot of the other places put cheese on top but not on the inside) and it was huge.  The hash browns were a bit undercooked but I didn't mind.  The wheat toast that came with it was mutli-grain and tasty, it came unbuttered and uncut (this is another oddity I have seen in a number of places) I assume they do this for those who prefer jelly.  The plus side is that they gave me a bowl with cups of fresh whipped butter rather than margarine.  The coffee was fresh and stronger than most diner coffee.   The service was great.  The place was pretty empty since it was 10:30 AM on a Tuesday, at various times my server, the busser, and the manager (owner?) came by to fill my coffee and ask me how everything was.  I'm used to family-owned Greek diners like this (they have them all over Detroit, where I grew up) and they always seem to offer up quality food with great service.  At one point an older Greek woman came in and the manager (who I assume is an owner) said "oh mom, what are you doing here?"  I got a kick out of the conversation, apparently she was waiting to go meet with the priest at the church across the street. Overall, great place for breakfast.  The menu was huge and I will definitely go back to try the lunch/dinner menu.

FIVE STARS FOR SERVICE. The coffee gets refilled like the beers at an indian casino.  Our coffee must have been attended to by four separate waitresses.  The customer truly seems to come first at Sam & George's. The skillets are what to look for.  They have about 30 of them, each with an interesting name, which makes me think they're smart restaurateurs.  Also smart were the carafes of water on every table, which is a huge plus. Our waitress was witty, friendly and attentive.  The gentlemen who appeared to be in charge personally greeted every person that walked in the door and thanked each and every person who walked out.  I am telling you, the service at this breakfast joint was impressive.  There are a lot of $25-entrée places downtown that could learn a thing or two from Sam & George.

This is definitely a breakfast place.  I've been here a lot, and we almost always get skillets - ok, today I got a burger - not the best choice.  I've had better burgers, but when it comes to skillets, like a hobo skillet or a la bamba skillet, well, this place gives any other breakfast joint a run for it's money.  Just remember, if you go here and are driving, try to find a spot on wellington (east of lincoln) since it's free from permits or meters.  the waitstaff here is fun and friendly - I've never had a bad experience at this place.  Highly recommend for an afternoon brunch.

The quintessential Greek cafe; exactly what I was looking for. Big breakfast menu, good food, pleasant help. What more can you ask for? The owner seemed to be on a first name basis with almost everyone who came through the door, which is always a good sign.  I'll definitely be going back, I love diners for breakfast.

Yeah, I did just rate Sam & George's above a Rick Bayless restaurant.  What of it?   Does Rick Bayless have an omlet called "The Hobo"?  No, he doresn't.  Point: Sam & George.  Bayless: zilch.  These guys are an old school diner, where the owner asks you how you're doing on the way in.  For breakfast, they make omlet dishes mixed with various ingredients: from italian sausage, to peppers, to Chorizo to mutliple kinds of cheeses.  And of course, they've all got funky names.  For lunch, they have the standard diner fare, and it is all good. Sam & George both rock.   "You haven't seen the last of me, Sam & George" - quote from Rick Bayless

Do you like a big pile of your favorite breakfast pickings tossed in a skillet and served piping hot and covered in two kinds of cheeses???  If you say YES PLEASE!  Then this is totally the place for you!  I am a huge fan of the breakfast skillet, there is something about it that is just so homey and comforting.  They have a massive menu, including nearly 20 different kinds of breakfast skillets, so no matter what your in the mood for with your eggs they're bound to have it.

For the diner genre, Sam and George's deserves five stars!  I had become discouraged that I could not find a decent little coffeeshop in the Lakeview and Lincoln Park areas.  Something basic but good food for breakfast, and a nice atmosphere.  This place more than fits the bill for breakfast, which is the only meal I have had here.  So many places can ruin breakfast: over or under-cooked eggs, tasteless hash browns, lousy coffee, bad toast, indifferent service.  Not here thankfully.  Everything was good from the bacon to the coffee to the eggs and toast.  Friendly service and congenial people.  I am glad I found it.

I'm definitely biased since I literally live half a block from this place.  However, I'd like to think I'm more objective since I've been there about 10 times.  This place really knows how to move people on a Saturday or Sunday morning for brunch.  And that's not a negative thing.  I have no desire to wait over a half hour for some eggs.  The owner is very attentive and really keeps things moving.  I have never waited more than 10 minutes to be seated.  The food is basic diner food, so it's definitely not the place to go if you're on a diet.  For diner food, it's awesome.  The skillets are delicious and SUPER filling.  The grilled cheese is amazing, super cheesy, gooey and delicious.  The only negative about this place is how packed the dining area is.  It definitely isn't a good place for a quiet, relaxed breakfast, but I don't think that's the diner atmosphere anyway.

Awesome place, but boy, they really pack you in.   I met up with a friend for breakfast here this morning.  The place was hopping and people were moving in and out really quick.  The service was great -- exactly what you'd expect of a diner.   I had the tex-mex and my buddy had the chicken coop.  Both were excellent.   My only complaint is that they really pack you close to the next table, so when you move in and out, you may bump into your neighbor.   2 coffees, 2 skillets set us back $30.   A little pricey, but not terrible for Chicago.   I will be returning.

Awesome little diner. Friendly staff and quick, good food. I may be a bit biased, but I think it's fair to say that you really can't go wrong with a Greek breakfast place and Sam and George's is no exception. The food itself was solid. A great breakfast/lunch place without being a total greasy spoon. Plus, they were very attentive with filling up coffee and water. That's always a huge bonus.

The friendliness of the owner gets 5 stars, greeting what I presume are regulars by name and treating everybody like a long lost friend. However, my breakfast was only ok.  The bacon was not as fatty or greasy as I hoped, and the hash browns were kind of bland. But due to the vibe, I will go back and give it another try and order something different.

I miss this place, used to live about three blocks away.  Definitely one of the best breakfast places in the neighborhood, especially if you're a 'skillet' afficianado as I am (they have like 30 different skillets, seriously).  Not a fan of the canned mushrooms they use, or at least used last time I was there.  Service is generally good and friendly, though expect at least a short wait on weekends.  Prices are average (I'm trying to get used to ten-dollar breakfasts, like everyone else).  I've had carry-out sandwiches and soups (for carry-out also) and they're quite good.  Their hours are shorter than many diners and can even be a little eratic, but that's why Golden Apple is across the street.  All in all, nice place.

I came here Sunday morning by myself for the first time.  A guy was greeting customers as they walked in and helped to seat them.  There was a counter for people to sit at, which I prefer when dining by myself but instead sat in a mini booth.  I ordered a 2 by 4 (2 eggs and 4 pancakes) with a side of hashbrowns.  It was pretty basic and delicious.  My food came quick and hit the spot.  My server was prompt and courteous and made sure everything was ok and kept refilling my coffee.   The the guy at the door said "thanks for coming  by" when I left.  I could tell there were regulars that came to the restaurant, which was a good sign for me.  And even though it was my first time there, I felt very welcomed.

We were tired and hungry . . .two of the three things that make me a "not so nice person" (in case you are wondering-the third thing is cold) but that wasn't an issue on this Summer's day, so the real "gremlin" in me did not come through. But food was in order and as we looked up and down the street, S & G's came into view.  "A diner! Yay! We shall feast for little money". . . .or so we thought.  As we pushed open the door of this corner establishment and heard and saw the bustle and din of a diner my heart leapt. Food and drink were only minutes away. We quickly seated ourselves by the window and perused the menu.  I could hear the cooks shouting out to their regulars encouraging people to order this or that before they ran out of it that day (probably should have listened to them). Now after looking at the reviews on Yelp- I probably should have gone with breakfast but it was lunch I was craving so I stayed focused on that part of the menu.  I ordered a turkey club sandwich with tots and a bowl of potato soup and my friend had the chili and a patty melt with fries. Still sounds good to me but the execution on a few of the items needed a little work. While my sandwich was good (and tots rule any day!) my soup was just okay- hot but tasting more like green peppers than anything else.  My friend didn't fare as well, however. He had asked for his chili to be topped with cheese and onions and when it came- not only was the chili not hot- the cheese was a slice of American cheese laid across the top! Never saw that before. And of course it never melted as the chili wasn't hot. And his patty melt? Came on white bread. A patty melt is only a patty melt when it comes on a nice rye in my book. Very odd for a diner of this type. And to make it worse- his fries were old and cold. Usually diners nail the basics!  Service was quick (thank heaven as I needed FOOD!) parking was a breeze on this stretch of Lincoln and the ambiance of the place, while a little 1980's was clean. Check out the bathrooms-as nice as they come.  The downside- it was a little pricey for a diner. We ended up spending almost $40 on lunch. Guess it might have been worth it if all the food had been great.  The good news? The gremlin in me was sated regardless and we were able to continue on our day without it rearing it's ugly head again. And for that I'm sure my friend thanks S & G diner!
Classic Diner food.  Solid, standard choices, but the friendly atmosphere and the owner there greeting you EVERY DAY make it a place worth seeking out.

We ate here once when another restaurant we wanted to try was closed.  I got the hash skillet and it was more than I could handle.  The amount of food was ridiculous, the waitress just kept bringing more and more plates.  Once I got over the extreme amount of food and dug in, I was amazed at how good it was.  Service was quick, staff was friendly, and the food was immense and delectable.  Unfortunately I moved and am no longer near here, but some weekend mornings I think of what might have been had I discovered this gem sooner.

Anyone that knows me knows I dont care much for diners.  Dont ask me why, maybe I just dont fully get the whole concept.  Anyway, for the whole time I have known Andy M, I have been hearing about Sam & George.  His dad has been going there since the actual Sam and George worked there and pretty much knows the whole family.  Finally the other morning we went for breakfast.  It is a small place and a tight fit in certain places, but the waitstaff has it down to a science, gracefully balancing plates and gliding around tables.  The inside possibly has the best diner interior I have seen in Chicago. Yeah its kinda hokey with the plastic plants and the big stained glass light fixtures, but man I have seen so much worse that this is actually OK.   As for the food, I had a half a grapefruit (good, how do you mess up grapefruit though...) scrambled egg whites and hash browns.  The potatoes were just 'eh", tasting too much of oil and not much else, but the eggs were great and fluffy, plus the coffee was really really good and never got past half full (they are very attentive about the refills!) If I have to come right out and say it, I have to say that S&G might be my favourite diner in Chicago.  Just dont tell Andy's dad cuz he will laugh, say "I told you so" and never let either of us forget it.  I guess theres a reason why a person would go to the same place for over 50 years!

I have been coming the S&G since I was a kid. This is my father's favorite restaurant.   The interior is cozy and bright, the family who runs the place are wonderful, and the servers do a great job.   The dinner selection is quite substantial. They have daily specials with everything from Steak, Liver and Onions to Country Fried steak.  They also offer a wide selection of burgers and Sandwiches.   In my humble opinion, the best part about Sam and George is the Breakfast menu. The Casseroles that they offer are huge, tasty and filled with fresh and delicious ingredients.   If you are in the area and want a taste of what a good old fashion diner can offer, stop on into Sam and George's. You will be happy that you did.

When I first moved to the area, I asked a friend to recommend a good place for breakfast and this was it.  It is now my go to place for breakfast--in fact I have only gone to one other place to meet a friend--because I can't justify not going to such an awesome place that is so close to my house.   This is not a fancy brunch place or a place with over-thought menu items, but is a great place to get a good solid breakfast or lunch (if you sleep in).  My favorite is the breakfast casseroles--hashbrowns, cheese, meat/veggies, and eggs your way on top.  I have also had a sandwich here for lunch, which was also delicious.  Most sandwiches come with soup and fries.  Even at peak times, the wait is never long--if you even have to wait.  The staff is fast.   Also, always, always order orange juice, no matter what time of day it is.  It is fresh squeezed and there are at least 4-5 oranges per glass--amazing.

I come here every Christmas (not Christmas day) with my father while I'm visiting from California.  My father is something of a friend of the co-owner (the Greek guy behind the counter, whose name is John). This is something of a (Greek) family-run place, but they're total Chicagoans. Parking isn't great, but it isn't impossible. The staff is great.  The prices are good. The last few times I've been there they've had a cook who overcooks the eggs, which is minus one star even though I really like the place. Omelettes aren't supposed to be brown.  Our waitress completely agreed with me and offered to take it back, but I declined (is he going to get it right the 5,000,001st time?)  That said, she didn't make me pay.   I've heard that their french fries are very good (I have secret knowledge that they buy them from a vendor, but it seems they do know how to cook them well). I noticed someone saying they liked to go to Golden Apple when drunk, but to S&G when sober.  Golden Apple completely sucks compared to this place.  The food is way worse and the atmosphere is way, way worse.  Also, I have at least once been offered brandy while having breakfast at S&G (so as not to get anyone in trouble, I will admit that the aforementioned occurrence may have actually been a dream).

When I was younger I was told never to go here (something to do with my deadbeat dad, blablabla) and then I find out a few years ago that my mom started coming here again!  Well I'll be.. All this time I had been going to the Golden Apple (because I lived in the area for about 10 years) and man, I wish I had come to S&G's earlier. The portions are nice.  I came here with a friend and was full on the soup and bread and barely bit into my sandwich.  That's cool, I had food to take home.  Now, this is what I expect diner food to taste like.  One of my favorite soups was a potato one (and I'm normally a chicken noodle lover) but cream of potato, or potato leek (it was one of those two)......you found a special place in my heart.  While I was away in school eating gross school food I learned to like soup other than Ramen, and when I come across a good one I always keep it in mind.   The owner is great.  I assume he's the owner.  Manager.  Whatever, he's great.  I took my mom here for brunch the day after Mother's Day and it was slushy and sucky out.  It was also the day they started the 24 hour meter parking.  He found out the hard way (and left his ticket on the car to show everyone) but had signs posted on both doors pointing this out and even making announcements every few minutes (as the place was packed and there was a moving line with new faces every time you looked up).   I've gotten so used to going to the Apple when my friends and I just want some diner food and I usually kick myself after we sit down and I look across the street.

We made roughly a 2 mile hike to get here (yay for being a tourist), and it was so, so worth it.  The service was quick and friendly and the food (two casseroles, one a Hobo Banquet and the other the Athenian with wheat toast) was perfect... Good mix of ingredients and nicely sized portions. They really aren't doing anything out of this world here, but the things they are doing are exactly right.

Consistently great food, friendly and competent service with a smile and laughter, and a welcoming atmosphere that makes you feel at home.  No frills - they don't mess around, because they know how to make a good, quality meal, and they know how to treat their customers.  I have eaten here for Sunday breakfast when it's most crowded, as well as mid-week lunch and dinner when it's quieter, and I have never been disappointed with any of their offerings.   Thank you S&G's!

The hollandaise on the eggs benedict was rather tart, but this made an excellent slightly-hungover breakfast place this morning.  The staff, especially the owner, is incredibly friendly, inviting, and familiar.  I also liked that the hash browns were slightly crispy and overcooked.  Everyone's afraid to cook hash browns crispy nowadays and that's a damn shame, because they're so good that way.  WHAT is the world coming to?  Anyway, here, they were crispy. That's all I got.

Though my standards for what qualifies as a great breakfast diner are pretty reasonable, there are only a handful of places in and around Lincoln Park that can pull it off. Sam & Georges is definitely one of them, and I'll be going back. I was greeted as (almost before) I walked in the front door by the friendly proprietor; both the booth and table were clean; I got a pitcher of water when I sat down; they had not just one, but two non-Tabasco hot sauces (Cholula and Louisiana); I never saw the bottom of my coffee cup; the server was quick and friendly, but not obtrusive; the food came out quick and hot but had obviously been prepared well; the atmosphere was pleasant and I could hear the person across the table from me. On top of all this, the prices were right in the sweet spot ($7-$9 for a skillet) and our server brought us a couple strawberries just to be nice. My brother and I both got skillets (Porky Pig and Spartan) and they were fantastic.

This is the happiest place in the world! Why do I say that?  Is it because the proprieter/cashier always has a smile on his face and a crack to make to you? Is it because of the friendly, chatty waitresses? Is it because everyone seems to know everyone walking in? And everyone walking in and out have gigantic smiles on their faces? In the end, it's because of the enormous, delicious egg skillets. Just try and find one you don't like. A do-not-miss breakfast experience AND the happiest place on earth.

Very good place.  Not my favorite, but right up there.  Very freindly staff, very good consistent food, reasonable prices (hard to find in Lakeview).  I actually like this place better for lunches and dinners.

Nomalicious diner food! Headed over here with a few friends this morning.  What a delicious find!  I'm a Jersey girl, so I take my diners very seriously.  S&G certainly meets my high standards.   I had pancakes that were tasty, but the egg casseroles appear to be the stars of the menu here.  There are 26 different kinds and they all looked totally yummy.     The only minus I can think of - I ordered a short stack and 2 eggs on the side.  When we got the bill, I saw that they charged me for the short stack AND a 2 egg breakfast combo.  I asked the waitress but she said they couldn't just charge me for 2 eggs as you couldn't order just a side of eggs.  WTF?   Don't go after 11:30 on Sundays - church gets out and the place gets packed!  And make sure you feed your meter.

One of the first things that I noticed when I came in and sat down at this place is that their menu says, "Open 7 days, 5am-11pm." That's funny. My boyfriend and I have been trying to come here for awhile now, and it always seems closed. 7pm on a Thursday? 3pm on a Sunday? We'd walk by and it literally appeared closed. Maybe it really wasn't. But the lights appeared to be off, and there was certainly no one in there. I felt like the menu was lying to me. But, nonetheless,  S&Gs is very much alive and open for breakfast times on the weekend. The wait staff is incredibly friendly. We didn't even wait a long time for our food, but the waitress came by, noticed my bf's milk was gone and profusely apologized that we had waited so long that he had finished his milk. She insisted on getting him another milk. "It's on me, I'll pay for it. I'm so sorry." The food was solidly good and Greek. Better than the Golden Apple across the street, but nothing to write home about. Still, it fills the greasy spoon diner hole that sometimes palpitates in my heart. Also, while we were there, I saw a salad come out that had tall stalks of Romain emerging like tall rabbit ears. And I peeped tater tots at another table. Those are two things that I might be compelled to try when I go back.

I really like this diner!! Everyone is so friendly here, you feel like you're at home.  The hash browns are amazing and so are the pancakes- I just had a regular order and they were out of this world- very sweet, just the way I like them!!  My friend got some kind of omelette with churasco in it which was awesome!!  Great location as well and you're seated very quickly.  Highly recommend.

dude, holy heart attack. defintiely a very solid choice for a greasy hangover cure breakfast. this place has a definite midwest feel to it...very laid back but friendly service. what we had: friend had pancakes, i had a skillet with avocados, hashbrowns (the good shoestring kind...the only kind), and an over easy egg on top...and it came with toast! holy moly! the bf had a biscuits and gravy greasy skillet. NOT a place to go for healthy fare, not a place with a very experimental menu (unless you consider their variety of skillets experimental), but definitely A-OK if you're in the mood for a tasty, fairly priced greaseball breakfast.

Have walked past many a time but went in for the first time on Sunday. I was not disappointed, great little food place. Very old school American feel to it, at least in my mind, which is a good thing. I can see this becoming a bit of a regular as a regular weekend brunch locale (watch out Wishbone)  And the staff and owner were super friendly in a character-ish type of way Ditto on why people queue for the Golden Apple, I mean that place did save a friends life after a day long drink session but a cozy place for brunch it doesn't really strike me as being.

Hands down, one of the best, most consistent spots for breakfast in Chicago.  Great staff, and excellent service. I have no idea why/how anyone can choose the god-awful Golden Apple over S&G.  It astounds us when we see the people lined up over there on the weekends.  Who are these people?  Do they have taste buds? My lone complaint about S&G is that they close far too early in the evening to take advantage of their dinner menu.

This place was nice - it reminded me of a New Jersey (where I grew up) diner. We had breakfast here. It was good - better than a Denny's or Golden Nugget - but no Tweet. Their prices were average which was good -  not to expensive.  I visited the restroom and it looks like they may have recently remodeled them as they were super new and clean looking. The only thing I did not care for was the coffee. I wish it was a bit stronger. I think one of the owners was sitting at the counter during our visit. He was quite loud, but entertaining none the less. He was very nice - as well as the waitress. It seems like one of those places where 'everybody knows your name' - like there are consistent regulars. I would visit here again if I was in the area.

When I first moved to my hood, I would alternate between here and Golden Apple, across the street. At this point S&G is my main choice. The food here is awesome and the portions are extremely filling. My coffee cup is never empty and the staff is really friendly. The breakfast skillets can not be beat. I would recommend the Porky's Cousin or the Godfather.

So the skillets are good and filling and great for a Saturday or Sunday morning. The service is good and you get seated pretty quickly.  BUT the fruit plate is what I come here for. For $10.95, you get huge pieces of fruit, including whole pieces like plums and pears, and it varies by the season. You also get some toast and a tiny portion of cottage cheese (this could be bigger)  So I would try to share a skillet (for the grease) and the fantastic huge fruit plate (for the healthy aspect, especially after a night out, get some antioxidants)  Also the owner is the nicest guy around and knows everyone in the neighborhood. Everytime I pass him on the street, he always says hello.

S&G's is everything a diner should be. Crowded and bustling, yes, but the service is quick, the coffee hot and for breakfast on a Saturday morning I haven't found better eggs.  This isn't a she-she brunch restaurant, it's a no-bones diner, and that's why I like it.  The pancakes were not so good, but the skillet I ordered was top notch.

I love S&G's.  It's the best place for breakfast or lunch in Lakeview.  The service is always good and you can tell they are working hard.  There's always a crowd, but I've never waited longer than 5 minutes and always get my food quickly.  The selection is outstanding - I highly recommend a breakfast skillet.

Yup, I love it even more.  Popped in for lunch today and overheard a great converstion between the regulars today...fast forward to conversation ending quote..."the worlds problems are solved at this very counter" HAHAHA lovvve it.

Woke up one hot Saturday morning with a hangover and a hankering for waffles with strawberries and whipped cream.  Got a table with no wait.  Staff was friendly but service was a little inattentive.  It's a bad sign when I can see the bottom of my coffee cup.  Water refills were not forthcoming either. The real killer though was the A/C.  BRrrrrRRrrrr!  I understand it's 85 degrees outside and they want customers to be comfortable, but cranking the A/C and blowing the cold air through high power fans is overkill!  If I'd known, I would have brought my parka. My waffle was cold before it hit the table.  The strawberries were defrosted, not fresh.  Waitress forgot the whipped cream, so I had to wait.  It was not the experience I'd hoped for. I also find this place to be a little too pricy for a greasy spoon diner.

S & G's brunch is divine because they have a list of about 25 different delicious skillets with tons of ingredients and fresh squeezed oj.  If you are hungover or just looking for a good, basic, kind of old school diner-y place for brunch that is very well priced, this is the spot for you.  However, Saturday and Sunday mornings are packed, and you may have to wait (but its worth it).

S&G is the greatest joint of all time. John and the gang are fantastic. The food is great, service is as good as any 5 star Resturant. If you have any questions feel free to see me at bar lunch time monday thru friday.

I used to live around the corner from S&G and would regularly go there for breakfast on the weekends.  The food was always good and pretty quick service.  The cleanliness isn't the best- the last time I was there the owner was wiping down tables with the same rag he wiped highchairs down with-pretty unsanitary  &  gross!!

I moved out of the neighborhood about a year ago, but I still make it back every now and again.  Great menu, good service.  Ruby, one of the servers, actually invited my sister and I to her house for Easter!  Now I wouldn't say we were there every weekend or week even, but she remembered us every time!  It's nice to go to the place where the staff actually cares about you!

This place is great!  I've been coming to S&G's for a couple years now, and it never gets old.  In fact, I moved out of the neighborhood a little bit ago, but I still make the drive and use this place as my "local" diner.

I found heaven on earth! Utopia! Shangra Lai! All right. Maybe that's a bit much. But oh how I love breakfast food and the skillets here are perfect! Do you love hash browns as much as I do? Then imagine a small skillet with an inch of perfect hash browns as the base of your meal. Two eggs and so many options to top it off I can't even begin to  list them. The end product is the perfect meal.  The menu is huge so you have plenty to choose from if you so desire. One day I'll get around to something else but for now I'm a skillet girl.

Ok folks hold on to your hat.  This place is awesome!  They have the best B&G in the city and it is always served with a smile.  We love the owner he runs a tight ship.  We visit S&G at least once a week.  The lentil soup is great and the Iced tea is fablous!  GO HERE! I'm Greek too Happy New Year!!!!
This place is awesome!  Huge portions, great food, and great service.  It's got that great little diner charm complete with a little old lady at the front desk.
A wonderful diner with wonderful diner food. What more do you need? I guess the family that owns and operates this diner being incredibly good people doesn't hurt either.

This is a local no-frills neighborhood greasy spoon that serves up heaping helping of good ol-fashion American breakfast.  And some days, this is exactly what you need.  And as such, they do a great job.  don't be looking for any gourmet fusion Asian-inspired French accented dishes.  I am sure they'll toss you to the sidewalk if you ask for soy sauce.

No nonsense - quick and friendly service with an ol' skool Chicago attitude... Their skillets are spectacular!  Neighborhood joint with lines out the door for breakfast (especially after church).   Don't get mad if the owner lets his regulars cut the line - he'll ask you to leave - and of course you don't because the food is so good.  I plan on becoming a regular and I'll cut the line!!!  Coffee is just okay - if anyone can recommend a good breakfast place with rich/bold coffee - pls let me know!!!

mmmmm S&G's is so good! Delicious breakfast! So many choices of breakfast skillets - anything you want! The staff is great and the seating and service is so fast!! I would recommend anyone coming here any day and anytime of the week!

I like this place better than the Golden Apple across the street. The waitresses here are super nice and right on top of things. Food was good and the fries need no salt. The best fries I've ever had.

I've been here for many lunches and a few dinners. Always a good spot. This is where waitresses have been here years. The guy at the counter knows you by name or at least by face if you've been in once in a while. Nothing fancy, nothing ground breaking, but some good soups, burgers, sandwiches and shakes.... tasty. I've always had a good meal here.

Outstanding grub menu. The menu alone takes up half the table top. There is no limit here to what you crave. Ideal to come here on an empty stomach. The portions do not skimp and the price can't be beat. So far, I've ordered my dishes on the greek side: Gyros sandwich(lunch) and "Athenian" skillet (brunch).  All Super Sandwiches come with soup and fries. Skillets are doused with eggs and built on hashbrowns.  Comfort food to the max! you'll definately take home a doggy bag here.

S&G gets five stars strictly on a diner scale. Compared to Sushi Samba, it clearly would not earn 5 stars, but compared to the golden nugget, it's way up there. S&G is a neighborhood diner with friendly staff and an owner who knows the value of greeting customers and making sure they have a good meal. The menu is pretty standard diner fare, and the prices are fair for the neighborhood. Every time I've been here this place has been full or very close to it, so you can expect to wait a short time for a table at peak hours.  If you're looking for diner food, you should definitely go here. It's worth a visit even if you don't live in the neighborhood!

I went there for a birthday brunch this Sunday and loved this place.  They have an extensive menu and the food is great. PLUS, the waitress we had was very friendly and even sang happy birthday to my friend, alone!  They order the desserts from a nearby bakery, so they are all very good. I tried the boston cream pie and it was GREAT.  I will be returning there!

S&G is such a great diner, and my husband doesn't let ANYONE stay with us for the weekend without making the trek there for breakfast on at least one morning of their stay.  It's a family-run kind of place with an incredibly friendly vibe.  Loads of regulars, but we were always welcomed with smiles and friendly greetings when we weren't regulars ourselves.  The food is delicious - the skillets, the waffles, and all the standard breakfast fare.  They also have healthy breakfast options, like turkey sausage and egg-white-only preparation or egg-beaters.  They have something for everyone.  Go early to miss a very long line!

Sam and George's is the Cheers of diners... Seriously...the mustached man in charge referred to just about everyone that walked in by their first names.  He was friendly with every single customer, including me, and I even caught him singing the Luna Carpet jingle...hilarious! They had a stack of Sun-Times for customers to borrow, not buy...love that! The waitress called me 'hon' and gave me delicious coffee and didn't miss a thing that I asked for.  My skillet was great and came out crazy fast, like under 5 minutes.  They have clever names, too.  I wanted to order the 'George Bush' but...I just couldn't...ya know, out of principle.. My only complaint is the booths.  The tables are attached so they don't move but are soooclose to you when you're sitting down, it's uncomfortable and awkward.  I just wanted to push the table away a bit but couldn't...ARGH!  I'm trapped.   But no matter.  I'll sit in a table next time and maybe mustachio will know my name by then...

S&G is a great diner in Lakeview.  We especially like their skillets, you can't go wrong with a skillet.  We've always had great service and the place is always hoppin'.  I think their lox platter is a bit expensive, but everything else on their menu is fairly priced. This is truly the last of it's kind.  A local joint where the staff remembers you and service is always on par.  The owner is hilarious and hasn't changed in years.  We always enjoy coming here and miss being the neighborhood very much.

Oh, S&Gs such delicious skillets! So much food you'd think you're going to burst! This is a great neighborhood diner.  Excellent food, wonderful people, it's the perfect place to cure your hang over with some good hash browns and eggs.  You might have to wait a little bit to get a table at the peak times, but it's always worth it. The menu is a little overwhelming but everything turns out well.

Skillets!  I love skillets!  especially when hungover. Excellent diner food.  Never waited more than 5 minutes.  What more can you ask for?  Well, how about a quick and very smiley staff?  Yes, they have that too.  Awesome.

Loooooove this place!  Spectacular breakfast... try the skillets!  Anything besides breakfast I can't speak for personally, though my guests were not as pleased with their sandwiches as I was with the breakfast.  Don't worry too much if there's a line when you walk in, the wait goes fast!  And don't forget the fresh squeezed juice!!!

This is one of those "neighborhoody" places where everyone is supposed to know the waitstaff since they've been going there since Kurt Cobain was in his first band so when it gets a large crowd, which it will do eventually, everyone can lament about "outsiders" taking it over. The fact is it's a very good eatery and the staff are friendly and will joke around with you once you're comfortable. The food is good and there's enough of it to not make you count the minutes until lunch. It's a good post breakfast/not quite lunch place for those that don't want to feel as if they have to be surrounded by people with hangovers just because they want a late breakfast. They have a wide selection of omelets and some good breakfast choices. Highly recommended. I'd suggest getting the morning paper, a nice drink, some good eats and just sit yerself down for an hour or so.

I love the Golden Apple when I'm drunk, but if I'm sober I'll usually head to the S&G instead.  None of the non-breakfast items at the Apple are any good, whereas everything I've had at the S&G is pretty respectable for diner food. The turkey dinner plate is unbeatable if you can't wait for Thanksgiving to get your turkey fix. Burgers are average and the other sandwiches are decent. They also have homemade soups daily which are always really good. The fries are the only downside to their menu. For breakfast, there's a million different choices. They have upwards of 30 different egg skillets with every combination you can think of. My only complaint about their breakfast is that the hash browns aren't as good as the Golden Apple. I think it has to do with them actually cleaning the grill. Overall, it's one solid place that I would visit during drunk hours if they were open late. What's really great about this place is the atmosphere. John is almost always there and is really friendly, at least when he's not yelling at one of his workers. I've overheard some of the most interesting conversations of my life while sitting at the counter here. One time I heard two older women discussing strategies for winning at Lottery scratch off tickets. I'm still trying to wrap my mind around that one. Another day two people were arguing about which casino offers the better frequent players benefits and has looser slots. My favorite story is a total stranger telling me how he went to a job interview high on LSD back in the early 80s. In case you're wondering, he didn't get the job. Give this place a try for either breakfast or dinner, you won't be disappointed.

Great place for breakfast!! If you're an egg lover, go for the skillets. I dare you to try and finish an entire one yourself. I have and it's not too comfortable on the tummy afterwards. You'll have to put off exercise, and maybe even walking after this one.  I used to go here all the time, but live up in Wrigleyville now so I don't get a chance to go as often. I should though, as Uncommon Ground is my favorite place up here, but the prices at S&G are much nicer on the wallet and quite suitable for a typical breakfast tab. Like other reviews, go to S&G. Don't waste your time with Golden Apple across the street.

I LOVED S&G's used to go there once or twice a week, I live a block or so away. UNTIL I was served a cooked roach in my chicken soup.... And when we summoned the waitress, she just took the soup away and brought the other soup of the day... AND they continued to serve the Chicken soup to others in the restuarant. We left , as well as the table next to us. I have since not returned.

S&G is a really good, basic Greek-owned diner.  But they work best when they are packed with people and forced to churn out tons of food.  (Last time I was there, I noticed there was a teenager whose only job was to continually load the enourmous toaster oven.) One of S&G's best features is their skillets.  AWESOME.  They have about 3 dozen different kinds of skillets which doesn't matter to me cuz I always order exactly what I want and they are thrilled to make it.  And they have a foot of onion rings which stack up on top of each other and are fun with a group of people. I would warn you to not go on Sunday mornings.  It is across from St. Alphonsus church and most parishoners head there after church.  Or if you figure out the St. Al's schedule and can go right between masses, you are set. **I have been to S&G at least 25 times in the past 4 years and can say it is consistently good, diner food.  Hope you enjoy it, too!

Sam & George's diner has a lot of flair.  Everyone in the joint had a smile on his and her face, including the staff.  It is hard not to enjoy your experience here when the service is so friendly and spot-on. I found the food to be average and the tab was pretty high for diner grub.  I had the BLT Deluxe that came with soup (I'd advise against the chicken and rice because it was a glowing-yellow color and it looked like it belonged in a tissue.  I did check out the matzo ball soup and that looked much better).  My boyfriend got the veggie omelet - solid, but nothing special.   S & G's is a homey place with lots of character. The atmosphere and the staff are truly one of a kind. For this reason, it stands above the Golden Nuggets/Apples/Pineapples of the world.

This is a great hangover food spot!  They've got an enormous menu of both breakfast and lunch items.  I had a chicken philly sandwich and not only was it huge, but it came with soup and fries!  We were stuffed before we left but even fuller after because everything was so good we had to finish it.  The price is right too!  Sometimes on the weekends there can be a little wait because everyone else loves this spot!

I heart this place.  I'm also surprised that the Golden Apple hasn't gone outta business being across the street from this place.  Oh well, no accounting for taste I suppose.  Great egg skillets.  Good people watching.   Good soup.

This place is the best. They have the greatest egg casseroles(skillets). When you first get there, the host, Jon will greet you. He is the nicest person. He usually remembers your name if you go there more than four times. The wait staff are also very friendly. They are quick and know what they are doing. Most of them having been working there for a long time. One of the waitresses is the sister to Jon, the host. Just in case you cared.

This place has been around a very long time. I used to live across the street when Sam and George were alive. They were two of the most cantankerous S.O.B's you can imagine. We would get thrown out for using too much ketchup....good childhood memories. I have not eaten there in many years,but remember the food being typical diner food.Probably more upscale now,as the the neighborhood has  gentrified.

Excellent service, excellent food!  This is the type of place that makes Chicago feel like a small town - the host(maybe he's an owner) is very friendly and welcoming, and seems to know about 2/3 of the people that walk through the door - he must have some memory.  This is the kind of place where, if your son/daughter has just moved to the 'big City', you'll be glad he/she found a place like this to eat a good hearty meal once in a while.  The breakfast skillets are just awesome and about the perfect size for a hearty breakfast appetite.  Five stars for sure, especially after our server called us by our preferred diner name - Hon.

The best diner in the city!  Also, the best breakfast skillets (or as they call them casseroles) by far.  On any given weekend you will see patrons waiting in lines outside for a chance to get into this family friendly diner.  The service is friendly and the quality is the best.  Everything is always fresh and delicious.  I will go back to S&G's as long as the doors keep opening!

I can't believe how many people prefer Golden Apple across the street. S&G is still a greasy spoon, but its food is good even when you're sober.   Your waitress will probably remember you if you have her more than once, it is always crowded on weekends but you never have to wait long, and despite the turnaround you never feel rushed.  I've moved out of the neighborhood, but find myself coming back here for a skillet on Sunday  mornings.

I'm probably biased about this place since my boyfriend took me here the morning after we, um...... well, you know (for the first time!).  So the place holds a special place in my heart, and will continue to do so, unless, of course, we break up.  At which point it will be too depressing to eat here.   Which would make me even sadder, since I love their biscuits and gravy (best hangover food ever!).  Their waffles are pretty good too, and they seem to have a gargantuan selection of skillets.  (I'm all about the breakfast food, people.) Most importantly, the service is spectacular.  The waitresses are friendly and everyone is just so cheerful.  Love it! Also, just an fyi: this place is WAY better than the Golden Apple across the street.

S&G, the best dinning experience in the city and it's your basic Greek diner. The food, it's average, but the service and the way they make you feel is unbelievable.  You will feel like family here, and if you come back a couple of times John, the owner, will remember you on a first name basis.   Hands down, best place to eat and if you like specialized skillets they have a ton of them.

What a great diner!  They are family run and the food there is soooooooooooo good (especially breakfast), I highly recommend the Porky pig skillet!  Oh my god is it good!  Their dessert selection is awesome as well and the service there is so friendly and fast.
